avalancheSummary: Over the last weekend, a very touchy combination of storm snow and surface hoar resulted in a widespread cycle of natural and easy-to-trigger slabs in the size 1.5-2 range. The snowpack on any steep feature was reactive to the weight of a person. By Monday, natural activity eased. Observations are limited to the far north of the region. We did not receive any new avalanche observations today. We suspect that the Thursday storm may have caused another round of small natural avalanches. Wind transport is suspected to have created wind-slabs that could be triggered by skiers or riders.
snowpackSummary: Early in the last storm, the surface hoar layer was extremely reactive (widespread avalanching and easy, sudden test results). More recently it has gained some strength (limited avalanche activity and moderate-hard, resistant test results). Strong winds from the south and then north-west have redistributed snow into wind slabs, especially in exposed alpine terrain. A melt-freeze crust layer exists around treeline below the storm snow. New snow combined with  moderate to strong wind created more wind-slabs on Thursday. The surface hoar layer is now buried by more than a metre of snow in the north of region. We have started to refer to the surface hoar as a persistent weak layer (PWL) in this region. It is yet to be seen how long this layer will persist, but it may be the most difficult problem to identify this weekend.

snowpackSummary: On average, snowpack depths are looking like 80-100cm at treeline and probably 150 in the alpine as of end of the weekend. That said, distribution is highly variable, so on a small scale you'll likely see bare ground beside areas with well over 200cm of snow while on a larger scale, one mountain or drainage may have significantly more or less than the next. By the time you read this, the current storm will have been going for 12-24 hours so snow depths will have increased accordingly and the upper part of the snowpack will consist largely of new storm snow in sheltered areas and new wind slabs in exposed locations. How much and how widespread this condition is will vary from northern and eastern areas (perhaps somewhat less) to south and western sections (likely somewhat more). I expect the storm and windslabs to be reactive for the next few days but I'll update in tomorrow's report if I get more solid data. There's some potential problems at the old/new interface and in the mid-pack including thin crusts and the November surface hoar, on which I think there is now general agreement that it's November 7th and is a persistent weak layer. It may not last as long as true winter surface hoar but it's down 100cm and has been around for 2 weeks so I guess a PWL it is. Even if these layers seem like they've died down a bit in the last few days, I suspect they'll reactivate in the next couple of days, perhaps not on a widespread basis but certainly locally on specific terrain (e.g. especially where no previous activity occurred). The deep snowpack is a bit of a mixed bag. I'm thinking probably some facets in shallow areas, more rounded in deeper locations and in many cases these layers will be moist at and near the ground. This is a general overview--I'm hesitant to get too specific this early in the season when data is sparse and there's so much variability. snowpackSummary: On average, I'm guessing nearly 100cm of new snow has been added to the alpine snowpack in the last few days. Figure half that at treeline. Below treeline it's probably a mixed bag of rain, slush, and snow depending where you are in the region and elevation. Here's my take, based purely on experience, what little information I have from a few select locations, and recent weather. Snowpack depths are looking like 100-150cm at treeline and probably over 250cm in the alpine. Distribution is likely still pretty variable due to winds and variability in storm track and intensity. On a small scale you'll likely see bare ground beside areas with well over 250+cm of snow while on a larger scale, one mountain or drainage may have significantly more or less than the next. The upper part of the snowpack consists entirely of new storm snow in sheltered areas and new wind slabs in exposed locations, both of which are likely settling rapidly with warm temperatures. I'm pretty certain the storm and wind loaded snow is unstable both at the new/old interface and within the new snow at various levels. How unstable and how long the instability lasts in lulls between systems and after this whole thing ends will relate primarily to temperatures. Click on the forecaster blog link below for a bit more detail on this. These layers and the associated problems are changing by the minute and hour so you need to stay on your toes. Settlement will be occurring in the midpack as well but crusts and the November 7 surface hoar, which could be down as deep as 200cm in some locations, continue to be a concern. If these layers have not been destroyed by previous avalanche activity, my gut tells me they are on the edge of the knifeblade and are capable of producing very large slides. I expect settlement is going on in the deeper layers as well. Still a mixed bag there though, with weaker facetted snow in shallow areas, stronger more rounded in deeper locations, and in many cases these layers will be moist at and near the ground. This is a general overview--I'm hesitant to get too specific this early in the season when data is sparse and there's so much spatial (and now with the ongoing storm, temporal) variability. The freezing level went up to about 1900 metres on Wednesday and caused some pretty rapid settlement, followed by below freezing temperatures that have re-frozen the snow pack up to about treeline elevations. The wind has come from the southwest during the last storm, and then strong from the northeast immediately following the storm. Yesterday the wind was strong in the alpine from the east-southeast. We were feeling pretty sure that there was a major avalanche cycle going on in the alpine, that we thought was probably failing on the buried surface hoar layer that has been reported to be down about a metre. Today we received new information from the Selkirks south of Revelstoke that there was indeed a major avalanche cycle up to size 3.5 during the last storm, but it appears that most of the avalanches were sliding on a layer that is near the ground; perhaps a rain crust from October. The slides may have started on the surface hoar layer and then stepped down to the crust. We hope to get some more information soon, as operators start getting out into the field. There is probably a lull in activity today (Friday), but I am hesitant to bring down danger ratings with the limited information that we have. The next storm is forecast for Saturday, and it looks like it is going to come in warm again, maybe up to 2000 metres. I think the "take home" advice from recent activity is that you should be very suspicious of any slopes in the alpine that have not recently avalanched.  If there is a crust of some type down low near the ground, you should be watching out for areas that might re-load with the next storm. Due to the variability of the amounts of snow in different drainages, I think that the absence of recent avalanche activity in an area would concern me as well. These are difficult early season conditions to evaluate. I recommend being very conservative this weekend. It is going to take a few days at least before we see any improvement. snowpackSummary: I still feel like I have more questions than answers in this region. I know that there is generally 200 cms of snow in the alpine. Some areas are bound to have closer to 250 cms. There was a period in early November when the conditions were optimal for the development of surface hoar. By the middle of the month when the first heavy snowfalls arrived, we were getting reports of widespread avalanche activity releasing on buried surface hoar from the few areas that were accessible. The snow has continued to build up in the mountains and the winds have been from strong to very strong from various directions. I suspect that the depth of snow in the alpine and at treeline is quite variable due to these winds re-distributing the snow that was available for transport. Last Thursday we had a report from the south Selkirks that there had been a widespread natural cycle of very large avalanches that appeared to have released very near to the ground. This type of activity would usually be because of some kind of early season crust that is thick enough and hard enough that it has not broken down in the 5-6 weeks since it has been buried. I suspect a rain crust because the avalanche activity was observed from several aspects, mostly north and east. If it is a rain crust, maybe it is limited to the South Selkirks? The warm storm that moved through the interior over the weekend deposited about 40-60 cms of snow. The new snow has been pretty heavy at all but the highest alpine elevations. The freezing level has risen to about 1800 metres, and the wind has been very strong out of the southwest. I would not be surprised to find out that natural avalanche activity has occurred on Sunday. Maybe the added load will cause some more avalanches to release down at the rain crust? If not, the new load and warm temperatures might help to settle the snowpack and promote bonding. If it gets cold, the deep weakness may continue to be a problem for a while.  I suggest giving the snowpack a few days to reveal its secrets. I will feel less uncertain once we have more operators reporting from the field.
